summary: This document is an email chain between prosecutors discussing the draft indictment of Jeffrey Epstein. The prosecutors debate how much detail to include about victims, balancing the need to demonstrate the case's seriousness with protecting victim anonymity and preserving investigative advantages.

persons.name: Geoff
persons.context: Mentioned as someone who will speak at a press conference about the case and needs material to convey its seriousness.

events.title: Draft Indictment Review
events.description: Prosecutors circulate and discuss a draft indictment for Jeffrey Epstein, debating the level of detail to include about victims and the case.

events.title: Email Chain on Indictment Strategy
events.description: Continued email discussion among prosecutors regarding the strategy for finalizing the Epstein indictment, focusing on victim protection and public messaging.

keyFacts: Prosecutors explicitly state a strategy to keep victim details sparse in the indictment to protect victim anonymity and to preserve the ability to vet new witnesses later.
There is internal pressure to 'bulk up' the indictment to instill public confidence in the case's seriousness, referencing 'the prior history' (likely Epstein's 2008 plea deal).
The arrest by the SDNY is seen as a key event that will itself communicate the case's significance.
Proposed additions to the indictment include paragraphs on the volume of victims, search warrant evidence, and the financial vulnerability of some victims.
The correspondence reveals prosecutorial concern about public perception and the need for a press conference strategy.
